title: How to Get Rid of a Toilet Bowl Ring

steps.title: Sprinkle baking soda in your toilet bowl.
steps.content: Sprinkle baking soda in your toilet bowl. Baking soda is an effective, natural, and non-abrasive cleanser that can safely remove the rings in your toilet. Simply open a box of baking soda, and sprinkle a generous amount around the bowl of your toilet. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Wait 1 hour (or longer).
steps.content: Wait 1 hour (or longer). Allow the baking soda to begin breaking down your hard water stains by giving it some time to sit. Set a timer, and let the baking soda sit for at least 1 hour. While you wait, place some diluted white vinegar in a spray bottle. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Moisten the baking soda with vinegar spray.
steps.content: Moisten the baking soda with vinegar spray. Used together, vinegar and baking soda create a powerhouse of natural cleansing. Take your spray bottle of vinegar and spray the inside of your toilet bowl. Use only a small amount of vinegar at a time, and add more as needed.

steps.title: Scrub the toilet bowl vigorously.
steps.content: Scrub the toilet bowl vigorously. Using a toilet brush, vigorously scrub away your rings. If it is left to sit in your toilet system for too long, vinegar can potentially cause damage to your toilet's inner-workings. In order to prevent this, be sure to flush your toilet at least three times after your scrubbing is done.

steps.title: Grab a pumice stone.
steps.content: Grab a pumice stone. Pumice stones are known for their ability to exfoliate and remove dead skin cells. If you have one of these objects lying around, it can do wonders for your toilet bowl! You can also purchase a pumice stone affixed to a stick--known as a Pumie--created for this very purpose. [3] X Research source If you'll be using a traditional pumice stone, you will need to submerge your hands in water, and you may want to wear rubber gloves and a plastic apron.

steps.title: Submerge the stone in water.
steps.content: Submerge the stone in water. Before you begin scrubbing your toilet, it is important to soften the pumice stone in water. Place the stone inside your toilet bowl and wait 15 minutes.

steps.title: Rub any toilet rings with the stone.
steps.content: Rub any toilet rings with the stone. Once the stone has softened a bit, simply rub it against the rings in your toilet. The pumice stone acts almost like a pencil eraser, removing hard water rings before your eyes! When you are finished, give your toilet a flush.

steps.title: Apply lemon Kool-aid to the toilet bowl.
steps.content: Apply lemon Kool-aid to the toilet bowl. Open a small package of lemon Kool-aid (available for $0.25 USD at many grocery stores). Sprinkle the Kool-aid powder all over your toilet bowl, making sure it covers the rings. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Wait 1 hour.
steps.content: Wait 1 hour. Once you have successfully applied the Kool-aid powder, set a timer for 1 hour. Make sure that no one in your household uses the toilet during this time. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub your toilet
steps.content: Scrub your toilet . Using a toilet brush, scrub the lemon Kool-aid into your toilet bowl. Work in a circular motion, paying particular attention to the rings. When you are done, flush the toilet. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Save your old dryer sheets.
steps.content: Save your old dryer sheets. Another effective tool for removing the rings in your toilet is a regular dryer sheet. In fact, used dryer sheets work a bit better than new ones! After you remove the clothes from your dryer, retain your used dryer sheets.

steps.title: Wear rubber gloves.
steps.content: Wear rubber gloves . This method for removing toilet bowl rings involves placing your hands into the toilet water. In order to avoid contact with germs, you want to wear rubber gloves.

steps.title: Scrub your toilet.
steps.content: Scrub your toilet. Rub the dryer sheet against the rings in your toilet and watch them vanish. When you are finished, give your toilet a flush. Dryer sheets can be used for cleaning your sink, tub, shower and any other surfaces in your bathroom, as well.
